timeline.message: Moves to new Brave parser types

timeline.bodyText: when serving the request from the response side. I'm thinking we ignore header mutations..
timeline.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: we could before, just htis will make that more explicit openzipkin/brave#1103
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

timeline.bodyText: is being lazy here (and in server) over-optimization from POV of armeria?
timeline.author: codefromthecrypt

timeline.bodyText:
I was sort of expecting this to accept HttpClientRequest as a parameter and passed in when initializing here
https://github.com/line/armeria/blob/master/brave/src/main/java/com/linecorp/armeria/client/brave/BraveClient.java#L162
I guess it does mean mutations would be present but is it a problem either way?
But anyways, reexposing, with the lazy instantiation, seems fine to me too.
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: this is part of me not knowing the lifecycle. I'm not sure if the instance could be different by the time we reach response time. is that something we cam know?
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: Instance is the same. In other words, the only difference between passing the originally created HttpClientRequest here or recreating it here is the value of headersBuilder, everything else should be exactly the same since it's the same ClientRequestContext.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: ok in that case, let's reuse it. thanks!
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

timeline.bodyText: Unrelated to this PR so just food for thought / another PR but just noticed it - since we pass the span to the handler, do we need to push the context (e.g. mount the scope)?
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: brave 5.11 doesn't mount the scope anymore intentionally, to improve performance (as scope handlers dangling off a thread local can cost a bit). instead the parsers get an arg for the context. the old implementation of the parser will indeed scope, but as handleSend/handleReceive are callbacks (iotw cul-de-sacs, not interceptors which would surround user code), we don't have any use case for scoping anymore internally.
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: Cool - yeah I think that means we can remove the request context push around the callbacks too that is there to allow brave to scope off the threadlocal but if it's not doing that it should be unnecessary.
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: I think we can revert the headers related changes now that we just serve the same request object
timeline.author: anuraaga
anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: I guess neither 3 nor 1 mean much to me. We probably should add a comment explaining what this is actually asserting semantically.
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Or we can remove if it's too strongly tied to implementation details to be helpful.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: yeah good point.. the reduction by two is not scoping during parsing :) I'll make a comment that the presence of 1 is for downstream handlers. usually I check some interceptor can read the context vs counting, though in this case counting was a good thing as it shows the better performance we should expect
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: added isOne as incrementing would be a bug unless intentional
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

timeline.bodyText: nit: span could be renamed back to customizer or spanCustomizer?
timeline.author: trustin

replies.bodyText: Personally good with span, Span, MutableSpan, and SpanCustomizer are basically the same concept.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: OK. No need to rename, then. :-)
replies.author: trustin

replies.bodyText: yeah we fixed the name to span upstream. naming parameter based on type was laborious
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

timeline.author: trustin
trustin
trustin

replies.bodyText: choosing not to unless you think this is very important
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: ditto on opting out, but if you really really want it to I can change it
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

timeline.author: trustin

timeline.bodyText: nit: request -> braveReq and response -> braveRes to avoid confusion
timeline.author: trustin
